supreme_leader.name: Ali Khamenei
supreme_leader.health_baseline: Advanced age (86), constitutional control over judiciary, military, IRGC, state media and Guardian Council. No major decisions occur without his consent.

power_centers.name: Supreme Leader's Office
power_centers.role: Ultimate authority over all branches of government. Constitutional control over judiciary, military, IRGC, state media, and half of Guardian Council.

power_centers.name: Assembly of Experts
power_centers.role: Body of ~88 Islamic jurists constitutionally empowered to appoint or dismiss the Supreme Leader. Members elected to 8-year terms after stringent vetting. In practice acts as rubber stamp - never removed a leader.

power_centers.name: Guardian Council
power_centers.role: 12-member body with veto power over legislation and elections. 6 clerics appointed by Supreme Leader, 6 jurists nominated by judiciary. Vets all candidates for elected office, disqualifying those deemed insufficiently loyal.

power_centers.name: Expediency Discernment Council
power_centers.role: High-level advisory and arbitration body. Resolves deadlocks between Majles and Guardian Council. Advises Supreme Leader on general policies. Members include senior officials from different factions.

power_centers.name: Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC)
power_centers.role: Principal defender of Islamic Republic since 1979. Answers directly to Supreme Leader, operates parallel to regular military. Central roles in internal security, strategic arsenals (ballistic missiles), commands Quds Force, sponsors allied militant groups abroad.

power_centers.name: Basij Resistance Force
power_centers.role: Paramilitary volunteer militia under IRGC command. Regime's grassroots enforcers. Integrated under IRGC control since 2007 to counter internal unrest. Deployed to quell protests and enforce social restrictions.

power_centers.name: Artesh (Regular Army)
power_centers.role: Regular army tasked with defending borders and territorial integrity against external threats. Kept largely apolitical and sidelined in strategic decision-making since 1979. Role confined to conventional defense.

power_centers.name: Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS)
power_centers.role: Primary civilian intelligence agency. Responsible for domestic intelligence, monitoring dissidents, counterespionage, and foreign covert operations. Works closely with IRGC intelligence units. Conducts assassinations, cyberattacks, arrests of journalists and dual nationals.

power_centers.name: Majles (Islamic Consultative Assembly)
power_centers.role: 290-seat parliament. Drafts and passes legislation, can summon or impeach ministers. Legislative power constrained by Guardian Council which reviews every law. All candidates must be pre-approved.

events.name: 1999 Student Protests
events.trigger: Shut-down of reformist newspaper by hardliners
events.geographic_scope: Tehran University and other campuses, spread to Tabriz, Mashhad, Isfahan
key_factors: Security forces stormed dormitories at night
President Khatami backed crackdown despite reformist image

events.name: Green Movement
events.trigger: Disputed June 12, 2009 re-election of President Ahmadinejad
events.geographic_scope: Tehran and dozens of cities - millions marched under 'Where is my vote?' slogan
key_factors: Basij and police used batons, tear gas, live ammunition
Green Movement leaders placed under house arrest

events.name: 2017-2018 Economic Protests (Dey 96)
events.trigger: Economic hardship and frustration with corruption
events.geographic_scope: More than 100 cities across all 31 provinces - working class/provincial areas

events.name: November 2019 Protests (Bloody Aban)
events.geographic_scope: Cities and towns across Iran - especially working-class areas
key_factors: IRGC and anti-riot police opened fire city after city
Regime demonstrated willingness to use mass lethal force

events.name: Mahsa Amini Uprising (Woman, Life, Freedom)
events.trigger: Death of Mahsa (Jina) Amini in morality police custody after arrest for alleged improper hijab
events.geographic_scope: ~160 cities in all 31 provinces - led notably by young women and men
key_factors: At least 4 demonstrators executed after rushed trials
One publicly hanged from crane as warning

groups.name: Ahwazi Arab
armed_groups: ASMLA (Arab Struggle Movement for the Liberation of Ahwaz)

information_control.doctrine: Regime uses internet blackouts as primary tool during protests. Playbook: shut down or severely throttle internet, cellular data, and messaging networks to hamper protester coordination and conceal crackdown scope. Depriving protesters of communication causes scattered demonstrations to 'peter out' due to lack of mutual awareness.

blackout_capability.technical_means: National Information Network (domestic intranet) enables state to keep critical services online for government use while cutting off global internet. Centralized control through Telecommunications Company of Iran (TCI).
blackout_capability.implementation_speed: Can achieve near-total nationwide blackout within hours

playbooks.historical_posture: Supports protests rhetorically and through sanctions on officials. Historically cautious about direct intervention. However, in severe crisis has signaled willingness to escalate: cyber weapons, sanctions tightening, even limited military strikes.
intervention_precedents: Contingency planning for kinetic action in extreme scenarios
playbooks.current_policy_baseline: Maximum pressure sanctions, rhetorical support for protesters. High threshold for kinetic action given risks of war. Would contemplate no-fly zones or strikes only to prevent mass atrocities or destabilizing spillover in extreme scenarios.

playbooks.historical_posture: Views Iran as most dangerous adversary. Will not permit Iran to acquire nuclear weapons capability. Active covert operations: sabotaged nuclear facilities (Stuxnet), assassinated scientists, conducted airstrikes on nuclear sites (2025).
intervention_precedents: Hundreds of airstrikes in Syria against IRGC/Hezbollah
playbooks.current_policy_baseline: Red lines: (1) Iran nuclear weapons - unacceptable, met with preemptive force; (2) Advanced weapons to proxies - continual preventive strikes; (3) Direct attack on Israel - retaliation on Iranian targets. Proactive, often unilateral operations.

playbooks.historical_posture: Strategic partner. Opposes external regime-change efforts. Provides diplomatic cover (UN veto), arms sales, some material support. But avoids entrapment in Iran's domestic turmoil.
intervention_precedents: Mild condemnation of Western strikes - no direct intervention
playbooks.current_policy_baseline: Politically/economically shore up Tehran, block Western intervention, encourage Iranian leaders to restore order. Opposes sudden collapse that could create chaos. Would stop short of direct military involvement inside Iran.

playbooks.historical_posture: Strong economic ties, supports Iran as counterweight to US influence. Overriding interest is regional stability and uninterrupted energy flows. Publicly emphasizes non-interference.
intervention_precedents: Continued Iranian oil imports despite sanctions
Possible sale of cyber surveillance/crowd control tech
Opposition to UN sanctions or regime change
playbooks.current_policy_baseline: Safeguard economic interests and energy security, avoid entanglement, oppose US-led intervention. Would tacitly support government restoration of order. Pragmatic - would swiftly seek understanding with any new authority.
